slug: /222
title: "This Week In React #222: CRA, React Router, captureOwnerStack, TanStack, CTRA, tRPC, Astro, Preact | RN 0.78, React 19, Expo, noCompress, JitPack, CRNL, Screens | TC39, Interop, TS, CSS, Node.js, Deno"
authors: [slorber]
date: 02-19-2025
---
This week we have 2 official blog posts from the React and React Native core teams! CRA is deprecated and React Native 0.78 is out with React 19 support.

segments.source_content: Long overdue, CRA has received the latest React 19 fixes and is now officially deprecated. This article explains the limits of the CRA and build tools regarding routing, waterfalls, code splitting, and more. The React team encourages us to adopt a framework like Next.js, React Router, or Expo to address these issues. However, you can still [build a React app from scratch](https://react.dev/learn/build-a-react-app-from-scratch) using Vite, Parcel, Rsbuild, or other modern build tools.

translations.fr: Attendue depuis longtemps, CRA a reÃ§u les derniÃ¨res corrections de React 19 et est dÃ©sormais officiellement dÃ©prÃ©ciÃ©. Cet article expose les limites de CRA et des outils de build concernant le routage, les cascades, le dÃ©coupage de code et autres. L'Ã©quipe React nous encourage Ã  adopter un framework comme Next.js, React Router ou Expo pour rÃ©soudre ces problÃ¨mes. Cependant, vous pouvez toujours [construire une application React Ã  partir de zÃ©ro](https://react.dev/learn/build-a-react-app-from-scratch) avec Vite, Parcel, Rsbuild ou d'autres outils de build modernes.
translations.en: Longtemps attendue, CRA a reÃ§u les derniÃ¨res corrections React 19 et est dÃ©sormais officiellement dÃ©prÃ©ciÃ©e. Cet article explique les limites de CRA et des outils de build concernant le routage, les cascades, le code splitting, etc. L'Ã©quipe React nous encourage Ã  adopter un framework comme Next.js, React Router ou Expo pour rÃ©soudre ces problÃ¨mes. Vous pouvez toujours [construire une app React de zÃ©ro](https://react.dev/learn/build-a-react-app-from-scratch) avec Vite, Parcel, Rsbuild ou d'autres outils modernes.

segments.source_content: The initial announcement sparked heated debates on X and GitHub, mainly because it overemphasized frameworks at the expense of build tools like Vite. It was [soon updated](https://github.com/reactjs/react.dev/pull/7624) to address these concerns. All this also led to potential collaboration opportunities between [Evan You (Vite) and the React team](https://github.com/facebook/react/pull/31768#issuecomment-2666856223) to work together on an opinionated "official" way to integrate with Vite with React Server Components, with a commitment to maintain this integration over time in the React repository.

translations.fr: L'annonce initiale a suscitÃ© des dÃ©bats animÃ©s sur X et GitHub, principalement parce qu'elle mettait excessivement l'accent sur les frameworks au dÃ©triment des outils de build comme Vite. Elle a Ã©tÃ© [rapidement mise Ã  jour](https://github.com/reactjs/react.dev/pull/7624) pour rÃ©pondre Ã  ces prÃ©occupations. Cela a Ã©galement conduit Ã  des opportunitÃ©s de collaboration potentielles entre [Evan You (Vite) et l'Ã©quipe React](https://github.com/facebook/react/pull/31768#issuecomment-2666856223) pour travailler ensemble sur une approche "officielle" et opinÃ©e d'intÃ©gration de Vite avec les React Server Components, avec un engagement Ã  maintenir cette intÃ©gration dans le temps dans le dÃ©pÃ´t React.
translations.en: L'annonce initiale a suscitÃ© des dÃ©bats animÃ©s sur X et GitHub, principalement parce qu'elle mettait trop l'accent sur les frameworks au dÃ©triment des outils de build comme Vite. Elle a Ã©tÃ© [rapidement mise Ã  jour](https://github.com/reactjs/react.dev/pull/7624) pour rÃ©pondre Ã  ces prÃ©occupations. Tout cela a Ã©galement conduit Ã  des opportunitÃ©s de collaboration potentielles entre [Evan You (Vite) et l'Ã©quipe React](https://github.com/facebook/react/pull/31768#issuecomment-2666856223) pour travailler ensemble sur une approche "officielle" et orientÃ©e pour intÃ©grer Vite avec les React Server Components, avec un engagement Ã  maintenir cette intÃ©gration dans le dÃ©pÃ´t React au fil du temps.

segments.source_content:
- ğŸ’¸ [Product for Engineers - How we choose technologies](https://dub.link/twir-feb19)
- ğŸ“£ [Vercel \- Support for React Router v7](https://vercel.com/changelog/support-for-react-router-v7): First-class support for React Router in framework mode with support for SSR on the new optimized Fluid compute serverless feature.
- ğŸ“– [React core docs \- `captureOwnerStack()`](https://react.dev/reference/react/captureOwnerStack): A new experimental React core API has been recently unflagged and is now officially documented. It is particularly useful for frameworks to enhance their custom error overlays. Unsurprisingly, Next.js is working on a new overlay that leverages this API ([example](https://x.com/sebastienlorber/status/1890361565960151374)).
- ğŸ“– [Vercel AI docs \- Duman-in-the-Loop with Next.js](https://sdk.vercel.ai/cookbook/next/human-in-the-loop): A recipe to prompt users for yes/no confirmation before LLM tool calls.
- ğŸ“œ [Introducing the new TanStack React Query integration](https://trpc.io/blog/introducing-tanstack-react-query-client): The upcoming tRPC v11 is in RC and leverages React Queryâ€™s `queryOptions()` to remove an abstraction layer: you can now use the native `useQuery()` instead of the tRPC wrapper.
- ğŸ“œ [Designing Backgrounds with LLMs and React](https://www.vigilant.run/blog/designing-backgrounds-with-llms-and-react): Tools like Cursor are quite good at authoring artistic React components.
- ğŸ“œ [Snapshot testing styled-components with Vitest](https://brightinventions.pl/blog/snapshot-testing-styled-components-with-vitest/): The existing StyledComponents Jest snapshot serializer is also compatible with Vitest. Iâ€™m not a fan of snapshotting styles and usually prefer [visual regression tests](https://docusaurus.io/blog/upgrading-frontend-dependencies-with-confidence-using-visual-regression-testing), but this might help existing codebases migrate to Vitest.
- ğŸ“œ [I like the future of Next.js](https://tigerabrodi.blog/i-like-the-future-of-nextjs): Thoughts on dynamic IO, PPR, and the `use cache` directive.
- ğŸ“œ [React "as" Prop Using TypeScript](https://playfulprogramming.com/posts/react-as-prop)
- ğŸ“œ [Client-Side Rendering in Flame Graphs](https://www.developerway.com/posts/client-side-rendering-flame-graph)
- ğŸ“œ [React Libraries for 2025](https://www.robinwieruch.de/react-libraries/)
- ğŸ“œ [Tanstack Start \- Is it the Next NextJS?](https://spin.atomicobject.com/tanstack-start-nextjs/)
- ğŸ“¦ [React Router 7.2 \- Type-safe `href()` utility](https://github.com/remix-run/react-router/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md#v720): A welcome improvement giving route path autocompletion and params validation. This release also include support for an SPA fallback static file, and 2 new future flags `unstable_splitRouteModules` and `unstable_viteEnvironmentApi`.
- ğŸ“¦ [TanStack Start 1.107 \- AbortSignal for server functions](https://tanstack.com/start/latest/docs/framework/react/server-functions#cancellation)
- ğŸ“¦ [Astro 5.3 \- Faster SSR, automatic session storage setup](https://astro.build/blog/astro-530/)
- ğŸ“¦ [Preact 10.26 \- Support for React 19 `<Context>`](https://github.com/preactjs/preact/releases/tag/10.26.0)
- ğŸ“¦ [9ui \- Beautiful, customizable components built with Base UI and Tailwind CSS](https://www.9ui.dev/): Using the shadcn distribution model but using Base UI, a new interesting alternative to Radix. The author is also porting popular libs such as Vaul and cmdk.
- ğŸ“¦ [Kokonut UI \- Collection of components built for Next.js and React with Tailwind CSS](https://kokonutui.com/): Another option using the shadcn distribution model.
- ğŸ“¦ [React Bits \- Collection of animated, interactive & fully customizable React components for building stunning, memorable user interfaces](https://github.com/DavidHDev/react-bits)
- ğŸ¥ [Alem Tuzlak \- Understanding the server/client boundary in react-router](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zyQjzId0H7s)
- ğŸ™ï¸ [Front-End Fire 81 \- State of React Results, TypeScript 5.8, and v0 Upgrades](https://front-end-fire.com/episodes/81/)

segments.source_content: Reactile is an UI/UX turnkey framework which features an out-of-the-box, intuitive tiling display with workspaces. It encourages parallel workloads for large web solutions within a single browser tab. Implement your own view containers, widgets and logic using React and let Reactile handle the display for you.

translations.fr: Reactile est un framework UI/UX clÃ© en main proposant un affichage par tuiles intuitif avec espaces de travail. Il encourage les charges de travail parallÃ¨les pour les grandes solutions web dans un seul onglet de navigateur. ImplÃ©mentez vos propres conteneurs de vue, widgets et logique en utilisant React et laissez Reactile gÃ©rer l'affichage.
translations.en: Reactile est un framework UI/UX clÃ© en main proposant un affichage en mosaÃ¯que intuitif prÃªt Ã  l'emploi avec des espaces de travail. Il encourage les charges de travail parallÃ¨les pour les solutions web complexes dans un seul onglet de navigateur. ImplÃ©mentez vos propres conteneurs de vue, widgets et logique avec React, et laissez Reactile gÃ©rer l'affichage.

segments.source_content: On top of that, Reactile also offers:

- A promise-based persistence mechanism which permits a uniform workflow across time and on multiple devices.
- The possibility to use nested tabs for your tiles.
- A simplified global search mechanism.
- CSS @container based responsiveness.
- And much more.

translations.fr:
- Un mÃ©canisme de persistance basÃ© sur les promesses permettant un flux de travail uniforme dans le temps et sur plusieurs appareils.
- La possibilitÃ© d'utiliser des onglets imbriquÃ©s pour vos tuiles.
- Un mÃ©canisme de recherche globale simplifiÃ©.
- Une rÃ©activitÃ© basÃ©e sur CSS @container.
- Et bien plus encore.
translations.en:
- Un mÃ©canisme de persistance basÃ© sur les promesses permettant un flux de travail uniforme dans le temps et sur plusieurs appareils.
- La possibilitÃ© d'utiliser des onglets imbriquÃ©s pour vos tuiles.
- Un mÃ©canisme de recherche globale simplifiÃ©.
- Une rÃ©activitÃ© basÃ©e sur CSS @container.
- Et bien plus encore.

segments.source_content: I bet you weren't expecting a React Native release so soon, but the team recently decided to releases smaller versions more frequently. Here are the highlights:

translations.fr: Je parie que vous ne vous attendiez pas Ã  une version de React Native si tÃ´t, mais l'Ã©quipe a rÃ©cemment dÃ©cidÃ© de publier des versions plus petites plus frÃ©quemment. Voici les points forts :
translations.en: Je parie que vous ne vous attendiez pas Ã  une version React Native si tÃ´t ! L'Ã©quipe a rÃ©cemment optÃ© pour des versions plus petites et plus frÃ©quentes. Points clÃ©s :

segments.source_content:
- React 19 support\!
- Simplified process to enable the React Compiler.
- Metro log streaming is back in 0.78 and 0.77.1, but opt-in with a new `--client-logs` flag, and still deprecated.
- `<Image>` supports Android XML resources, unlocking possible perf improvements.
- `ReactNativeFactory` on iOS to ease brownfield usage in any ViewController

translations.fr:
- Prise en charge de React 19 !
- Processus simplifiÃ© pour activer le React Compiler.
- Le streaming des logs Metro est de retour en 0.78 et 0.77.1, mais en option avec un nouveau flag `--client-logs`, et toujours dÃ©prÃ©ciÃ©.
- `<Image>` prend en charge les ressources XML Android, dÃ©bloquant des amÃ©liorations potentielles de performances.
- `ReactNativeFactory` sur iOS pour faciliter l'utilisation brownfield dans n'importe quel ViewController
translations.en:
- Prise en charge de React 19 !
- Processus simplifiÃ© pour activer le React Compiler.
- La diffusion des logs Metro est de retour en 0.78 et 0.77.1, mais en option via le nouveau flag `--client-logs`, et toujours dÃ©prÃ©ciÃ©e.
- `<Image>` prend dÃ©sormais en charge les ressources XML Android, permettant des gains de performance potentiels.
- `ReactNativeFactory` sur iOS pour faciliter l'utilisation brownfield dans n'importe quel ViewController.

segments.source_content: React 19 itself unlocks many cool things:

translations.fr: React 19 lui-mÃªme dÃ©bloque de nombreuses fonctionnalitÃ©s intÃ©ressantes :
translations.en: React 19 lui-mÃªme dÃ©verrouille de nombreuses fonctionnalitÃ©s intÃ©ressantes :

segments.source_content:
- Actions (async transitions), `useActionState()`, `useOptimistic()`, all useful to submit forms and manage loading, error, and optimistic state
- Use `ref` as a regular prop instead of `forwardRef()`, also supporting a ref cleanup function
- Use `<Context>` instead of `<Context.Provider>`
- Read contexts and promises with `use()`

translations.fr:
- Actions (transitions asynchrones), `useActionState()`, `useOptimistic()`, tous utiles pour soumettre des formulaires et gÃ©rer les Ã©tats de chargement, d'erreur et optimiste
- Utiliser `ref` comme prop rÃ©guliÃ¨re au lieu de `forwardRef()`, prenant Ã©galement en charge une fonction de nettoyage de ref
- Utiliser `<Context>` au lieu de `<Context.Provider>`
- Lire les contextes et promesses avec `use()`
translations.en:
- Actions (transitions asynchrones), `useActionState()`, `useOptimistic()`, tous utiles pour soumettre des formulaires et gÃ©rer les Ã©tats de chargement, d'erreur et optimiste
- Utiliser `ref` comme prop standard au lieu de `forwardRef()`, avec prise en charge d'une fonction de nettoyage pour les refs
- Utiliser `<Context>` au lieu de `<Context.Provider>`
- Lire les contextes et promesses avec `use()`

segments.source_content:
- ğŸ’¸ [Codemagic - a great App Center alternative for React Native devs! 8x faster builds, CodePush, automated distribution. 1-month free trial!](https://codemagic.io/migration-from-app-center/?utm_source=newsletter&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=app_center_this_week_react)
- ğŸ“£ [Expo support for React Native 0.78](https://expo.dev/changelog/react-native-78): Due to the React 19 upgrade, v0.78 will not be supported in SDK52, but will be in the canary version. SDK 53 is scheduled for this spring and will likely upgrade directly to 0.79.
- ğŸ‘€ [Gradle Plugin PR \- Add option to disable bundle compression](https://github.com/facebook/react-native/pull/49449): Marc Rousavy proposing a `react.enableBundleCompression` Gradle property. Turning it off could greatly optimize Android app startup time became (and is now the new default), but it also increases the app install size.
- ğŸ’¬ [Making the JitPack Repository optional](https://github.com/react-native-community/discussions-and-proposals/discussions/877): Android apps With v0.78, Android apps have a new `react.includeJitpackRepository=true` Gradle property. Turning it off could improve supply chain security, and may become the default in the future.
- ğŸ“œ [Checkbox Interactions \- The beauty of Layout Animations](https://reactiive.io/articles/checkbox-interactions)
- ğŸ“œ [Universal App with Expo](https://www.premieroctet.com/blog/en/universal-app-with-expo)
- ğŸ“¦ [Create React Native Library 0.48 \- Support for Nitro modules](https://github.com/callstack/react-native-builder-bob/releases/tag/create-react-native-library%400.48.0)
- ğŸ“¦ [React Native Screens 4.7 \- Fix Android formSheet transition](https://github.com/software-mansion/react-native-screens/releases/tag/4.7.0)
- ğŸ“¦ [Expo AI Chatbot \- Starter to build a universal Expo \+ Next.js chatbot with premium option](https://www.expoaichatbot.com/)
- ğŸ¥ [Expo \- EAS Workflows: React Native CI/CD for app developers](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OJ2u9tQCpr4)
- ğŸ¥ [Catalin Miron \- Apple Invites animation](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=P_gYeiFipsk)
- ğŸ¥ [Simon Grimm \- The Fastest Way to Build a Mobile App (AI \+ Expo \= Magic)](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fJb6f2Sw4Ek)
- ğŸ™ï¸ [React Universe On Air 48 \- Reanimated 4 is the Future of Smooth React Native Animations](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wAfJqFX62ag)

segments.source_content:
- ğŸ“£ [TC39 \- Agenda for the 106th meeting](https://github.com/tc39/agendas/blob/main/2025/02.md): Meeting in progress. Great proposals have already progressed, including `RegExp.escape()`, `import defer`, `Math.clamp(),` and more.
- ğŸ“£ [Interop 2025](https://web.dev/blog/interop-2025): Browsers agreed to work in priority on exciting features such as CSS anchor positioning, View Transition API, Navigation API, and many others.
- ğŸ“£ [ESLint now officially supports linting of CSS](https://eslint.org/blog/2025/02/eslint-css-support/)
- ğŸ“œ [Bundling dependencies (and when not to do it)](https://e18e.dev/blog/bundling-dependencies.html)
- ğŸ“œ [CSS @function \+ CSS if() \= ğŸ¤¯](https://www.bram.us/2025/02/18/css-at-function-and-css-if/)
- ğŸ“œ [Mocking in Node.js Has Just Changed Forever](https://kettanaito.com/blog/mocking-in-nodejs-has-just-changed-forever)
- ğŸ“¦ [TypeScript 5.8 RC \- `erasableSyntaxOnly`\` , `require(esm)`, dependent return type narrowing](https://devblogs.microsoft.com/typescript/announcing-typescript-5-8-rc/)
- ğŸ“¦ [Node 23.8 \- `URLPattern` API, thread names, zstd compression, using system CA](https://nodejs.org/en/blog/release/v23.8.0)
- ğŸ“¦ [Node 22.14 \- `findPackageJSON`, glob `exclude`, Corepack pnpm fix](https://nodejs.org/en/blog/release/v22.14.0)
- ğŸ“¦ [Deno 2.2 \- OpenTelemetry, Lint Plugins, `node:sqlite`](https://deno.com/blog/v2.2)
